data:
Hi there,
As you are a year ahead of me, could I get a little help finding housing for me for this next Fall term at OSU? I tried looking at Craigslist, but I can’t tell what’s good and what’s not!
I’m on a budget, so let’s keep it under $700 a month. And no roommate! If you can, find a place that doesn’t accept cats or dogs. Please send me links to the best place or two that you find!
Thank you ever so much, 
Myrcella

Hey Myrcella,

 

I found a one bedroom and a studio with these specifications, and attached the links to both.  

1 bedroom:  http://corvallis.craigslist.org/apa/5772867666.html

Studio:  http://corvallis.craigslist.org/apa/5778133888.html 

Hopefully these are helpful.

 

-Chucky Chatty

 

From: Myrcella Baratheon [mailto:myrcella.baratheon@oregonstate.edu] 
Sent: Wednesday, September 14, 2016 1:10 PM
To: Chatsworth, Charles <Charles.Chatsworth@oregonstate.edu>
Subject:  Housing... OMG!

 

Hi there,
As you are a year ahead of me, could I get a little help finding housing for me for this next Fall term at OSU? I tried looking at Craigslist, but I can’t tell what’s good and what’s not!
I’m on a budget, so let’s keep it under $700 a month. And no roommate! If you can, find a place that doesn’t accept cats or dogs. Please send me links to the best place or two that you find!
Thank you ever so much, 
Myrcella

Hi!
 
There’s a picnic in the woods near Alsea that we’re supposed to go to this weekend. We may also hike to the waterfall. Can you please check the weather and let me know what I should wear and if I should bring sunscreen?
 
Thank you, 
 
Myrcella

Myrcella,

 

You chose a splendid time and location for a picnic.  There is a 0 to 10% chance of rain in Alsea throughout the weekend, and a mixture of sunny and clear skies forecasted with temperatures ranging from approximately 50 degrees Fahrenheit to 80 degrees Fahrenheit.  Sunscreen is a good idea to bring, but you’ll likely only need it Friday.  Short sleeves with shorts should cut it for during the days, but for the chillier nights and mornings bring a jacket and/or pants.  

 

-Chucky Chatty

 

From: Myrcella Baratheon [mailto:myrcella.baratheon@oregonstate.edu] 
Sent: Wednesday, September 14, 2016 1:18 PM
To: Chatsworth, Charles <Charles.Chatsworth@oregonstate.edu>
Subject:  Weather?

 

 

Hi!

 

There’s a picnic in the woods near Alsea that we’re supposed to go to this weekend. We may also hike to the waterfall. Can you please check the weather and let me know what I should wear and if I should bring sunscreen?

 

Thank you, 

 

Myrcella

Dr. Chatty,




Thank you oh so much for the information!




Myrcella

	Myrcella,

	 

	You chose a splendid time and location for a picnic.  There is a 0 to 10% chance of rain in Alsea throughout the weekend, and a mixture of sunny and clear skies forecasted with temperatures ranging from approximately 50 degrees Fahrenheit to 80 degrees Fahrenheit.  Sunscreen is a good idea to bring, but you’ll likely only need it Friday.  Short sleeves with shorts should cut it for during the days, but for the chillier nights and mornings bring a jacket and/or pants.  

	 

	-Chucky Chatty

	Myrcella

Hello Charles,
 
I am planning an event at my sorority this weekend and I could use some ideas for food to make as appetizers. I am expecting to have 20 people at the event and would like to include options for those who are vegetarian or gluten free. I will have about an hour to make these ahead of time so please keep that in mind as you research. It’s really important that people love the event, so try and pick some recipes that people will rave about!
 
Please email me three or four recipes that I can consider for appetizers.  
 
Thank you, 
 
Myrcella

Hello again Myrcella,

 

I am including links to three recipes to help you achieve your crowd-pleasing desires.  All of these ideas are quick, simple, and can be adjusted to accommodate vegetarians/vegans.

 

1.       Antipasto:  http://www.wholefoodsmarket.com/recipes/cooking-entertainment-guides/perfect-antipasto-plate

2.       Vegetable Tempura:  http://veganyumyum.com/2009/02/vegetable-tempura/

3.       Falafel burgers: http://www.bbcgoodfood.com/recipes/5605/falafel-burgers 

 

Good luck!

 

-Chucky Chatty

 

 

From: Myrcella Baratheon [mailto:myrcella.baratheon@oregonstate.edu] 
Sent: Wednesday, September 14, 2016 1:25 PM
To: Chatsworth, Charles <Charles.Chatsworth@oregonstate.edu>

Thank you, 

 

Myrcella

Chatty Chucky,




Thanks for helping me please the crowds!




Myrcella

Hello Charles,
 
Just a friendly reminder that I’ll need the following two books soon and you promised to help me buy them for a good price! :)
 
Please find them wherever you can, just make sure you will receive them by next week for classes. My budget is at most 200 dollars to get these two textbooks, but please please please try and find the best available prices.
 
Textbooks Needed:
Engineering Economic Analysis by Donald Newnan 12th edition IBSN: 978-0199339273
 
Robert Love, Linux Kernel Development 3/e, Addison-Wesley, 2010, ISBN: 978-1-672-32946-3
 
Email me back with where to buy them for the best price so they’ll arrive next week! I owe you lunch for this big help!
 
Thanks! :) :) :)
Myrcella

Myrcella,

 

With the extra 100 dollars you will be saving due to the super cheap book prices I am sending you links to, I will accept payment in the form of surf and turf.

 

Engineering Book:  https://www.amazon.com/ENGR-ECONOMIC-ANALYSIS-STUDY-GUIDE-Donald-Newnan/dp/0199339341/ref=mt_paperback?_encoding=UTF8&me= 

 

Linux Book:  https://www.amazon.com/Linux-Kernel-Development-Robert-Love/dp/0672329468/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1473885425&sr=8-1&keywords=Robert+Love%2C+Linux+Kernel+Development+3%2Fe%2C+Addison-Wesley%2C+2010 

 

-Chucky Chatty

Thanks! :) :) :)

Myrcella

Hi, Charles ,

 

Game of Thrones season six is over and I really need something new to watch! I just don’t know what would be good. 

 

I’m a big fan of action dramas such as House of Cards and Homeland (all of which I’ve already seen, unfortunately). 

 

What’s the next best show after these three? I don’t want to be fooled into watching something bad, so please see if the critics agree that the show is really excellent. Some rankings would also help give me confidence the show will be worthwhile.

 

Thank you so much! 


Melisandre

Hi Melisandre,

 

That’s a real shame that you’re done throning for a whole year, I’m in the same boat myself.  Fortunately, I am aware of several critically acclaimed action drama series that should even be pleasing to a Lannister such as yourself.  I am listing three possible shows you’d enjoy with links to critics’ reviews for each.  

 

The Night of: https://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/the_night_of/s01/ 

Dexter:  https://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/dexter/ 

Sons of Anarchy:  https://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/sons_of_anarchy

 

Enjoy!

-Chucky

Sent: Wednesday, September 14, 2016 1:47 PM
To: Chatsworth, Charles <Charles.Chatsworth@oregonstate.edu>
Subject:  Best TV Show to Watch

Melisandre

I’ve heard a lot of good things about Jax Teller :) Thanks for the links. The reviews are good, so I think I’ll give SOA a try :)

 

--Mel

Hi there!

 

I need to buy a gift for a friend.

 

My friend loves the outdoors and the color pink.

She’s 22 years old and her birthday is in a week (7 days).

I will need something that will get here on time.

Nothing that will take too long to ship please.

 

I have 30 dollars to spend on my friend.

Please spend as close to that as you can.

 

Please email me the link(s) to the gift(s) you find and include how much they cost.

 

Thank you,

Melisandre

Mel,

 

I found just the thing for your friend.  With these pink rain boots (link attached), your friend will be able to frolic around the outdoors, in style, even in the winter months of Oregon, with free two-day shipping for under $30.      https://www.amazon.com/Capelli-New-York-Shiny-Ladies/dp/B00D3PP63K/ref=sr_1_8?ie=UTF8&qid=1473887315&sr=8-8&keywords=pink+rain+boots 

 

-Chucky

Hi there,

 

I heard from a friend that you are the one to talk to about this subject.

 

Unfortunately, my friend has to take two strong medications together - Adderall, and Valium. Are there any issues (contraindications) with taking them both together? Is there anything (food, activities, etc.) that he needs to avoid? I just want him to be safe. Please send a list of what you find, along with links to your resources.

 

Thanks for volunteering to check it out!

 

Davos

Hi Davos,

 

Fortunately, there aren’t any drug interactions between Adderall and valium in the human body.  Acidic foods and vitamin c supplements should be taken in moderation when taking Adderall to avoid digestive system damage.  Additionally, it is bad for the cardiovascular and respiratory systems to take additional stimulants like caffeine in large doses while on Adderall (source: http://www.livestrong.com/article/322871-foods-to-avoid-when-taking-adderall).  Avoid ingesting any alcohol when on valium (source:    http://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-11116/valium-oral/details/list-interaction-food).  I hope your friend doesn’t have to take these meds for much longer.  

 

-Chuck  

 

From: Stark, Davos 
Sent: Wednesday, September 14, 2016 4:20 PM
To: Chatsworth, Charles <Charles.Chatsworth@oregonstate.edu>
Subject:  check on medication

 

Hi there,

 

I heard from a friend that you are the one to talk to about this subject.

 

Unfortunately, my friend has to take two strong medications together - Adderall, and Valium. Are there any issues (contraindications) with taking them both together? Is there anything (food, activities, etc.) that he needs to avoid? I just want him to be safe. Please send a list of what you find, along with links to your resources.

 

Thanks for volunteering to check it out!

 

Davos

Seems like my friend has to be careful about a lot of things. I’m glad I asked you about this, Chuck. My friend is just a stubborn kind of guy who doesn’t like going to the doctor. I don’t even know why he’s having to take these meds!

 

Sigh. Thanks again.

Davos

Avoid ingesting any alcohol when on valium (source:    http://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-11116/valium-oral/details/list-interaction-food).  I hope your friend doesn’t have to take these meds for much longer.  

 

-Chuck

Hello Charles,

 

I know graduating is coming up soon for you. It would be good to do a preliminary job search. Please find at least 1 job and send me an email with the link(s) to the job(s) you applied for. 

 

 

Here is the link for one job search site to get started. 

 

http://www.indeed.com 

 

Job criteria: 

 

You should find a computer engineering job. 

 

Must start after September 2016.

 

For now, just find one or more jobs you believe will work out well. We can talk about them further at our next meeting.

 

Sincerely, 

 

Davos

Hey Davos,

 

Here is a link to a job I shall apply for:  http://globalcxaccenture.avature.net/opportunities/JobDetail/Nationwide-Nationwide-United-States-Java-Developer/642?source=Indeed&jobId=642 

 

-Chuck

Hello Charles, 

 

I am your academic advisor. 

 

Below is a list of classes you must enroll in for Fall Term 2016 (yes, it’s actually still summer right now): 

 

ST 314 

PAC 201 

WR 121 

COMM 111 

H 100 

Note** Do not worry if there is no space in the class. I will make sure you get a spot in the class. 

 

In order to view the available times for these classes please use the OSU catalog <http://catalog.oregonstate.edu/Default.aspx?section=Course> . 

 

Please provide me with a list of the CRNs so that I can finish your registration process. 

Once you have been registered, I will provide you with the list of textbooks you will need for your classes. Since the textbook selection will be shared, we require all textbooks be acquired legally. 

 

Thank you, 

Professor Targaryen

Greetings, traveler,

 

I hear you’re are interested in exploring Eastern Europe with our group. Recently the group is wondering whether or not it is safe to travel right now. We need to do some research and see what we can find out.

 

The plan is to land in Istanbul. Next, we will be traveling to Sofia, the capital of Bulgaria.  After Sofia, the next step is some car travel to Macedonia and then onwards to Albania. Our last stop will be Tirana, in Albania.

 

The group would like to have some information sent to me to start this travel planning out:

 

A quick overview of each country’s political climate - I don’t want anyone getting into trouble and having this turn into some geopolitical affair! Is the country at war with a US ally? Is the country in political turmoil? Is there a US embassy? Is it safe to travel there now?

 

This will be a good start for the travel planning. Please research these items and send the information to me right away.

 

Kind regards,

Davos Stark

Eastern Reaches, an OSU Travel Group

Davos,

 

One should exercise caution when travelling to Istanbul in light of recent terrorist attacks.  Fortunately, there is an American Consulate in Istanbul, and aside from the terrorist attacks in late June, there hasn’t been much additional turmoil.  

 

Similarly, although it is generally regarded as safe to travel to Bulgaria, one must be cautious.  Avoid confrontations with aggressive drivers and con artists, and be mindful of potential theft.  There is a U.S. embassy in Sofia.

 

Macedonia is among the safer locations on this list.  Crime is rare, but be mindful of theft and avoid aggressive protests.  There is a U.S. embassy in Skopje, Macedonia.

 

As for Albania, crimes such as drug-related violence, theft, and carjacking are relatively common.  It is advisable to remain vigilant when parking in unattended areas and inspect vehicles for suspicious items including improvised explosives.  There is a U.S. embassy in Tirana.  

 

Be very careful on this trip…

 

-Chuck

 

From: Stark, Davos 
Sent: Wednesday, September 14, 2016 4:04 PM
To: Chatsworth, Charles <Charles.Chatsworth@oregonstate.edu>
Subject:  travel planning

The group would like to have some information sent to me to start this travel planning out:

 

A quick overview of each country’s political climate - I don’t want anyone getting into trouble and having this turn into some geopolitical affair! Is the country at war with a US ally? Is the country in political turmoil? Is there a US embassy? Is it safe to travel there now?

 

This will be a good start for the travel planning. Please research these items and send the information to me right away.

 

Kind regards,

Davos Stark

Eastern Reaches, an OSU Travel Group

Chuck, it really sounds like we shouldn’t go! At least this year. You’ve uncovered a lot of good information for the group to discuss at our next meeting. Hopefully we can figure something out!

 

Thanks,

Davos

 

From: Chatsworth, Charles 
Sent: Wednesday, September 14, 2016 4:18 PM
To: Stark, Davos <Davos.Stark@oregonstate.edu>
Subject: RE:  travel planning

 

Davos,

 

One should exercise caution when travelling to Istanbul in light of recent terrorist attacks.  Fortunately, there is an American Consulate in Istanbul, and aside from the terrorist attacks in late June, there hasn’t been much additional turmoil.  

 

Similarly, although it is generally regarded as safe to travel to Bulgaria, one must be cautious.  Avoid confrontations with aggressive drivers and con artists, and be mindful of potential theft.  There is a U.S. embassy in Sofia.

 

Macedonia is among the safer locations on this list.  Crime is rare, but be mindful of theft and avoid aggressive protests.  There is a U.S. embassy in Skopje, Macedonia.

 

As for Albania, crimes such as drug-related violence, theft, and carjacking are relatively common.  It is advisable to remain vigilant when parking in unattended areas and inspect vehicles for suspicious items including improvised explosives.  There is a U.S. embassy in Tirana.  

 

Be very careful on this trip…

 

-Chuck

 

From: Stark, Davos

Subject:  travel planning

 

Greetings, traveler,

 

I hear you’re are interested in exploring Eastern Europe with our group. Recently the group is wondering whether or not it is safe to travel right now. We need to do some research and see what we can find out.

 

The plan is to land in Istanbul. Next, we will be traveling to Sofia, the capital of Bulgaria.  After Sofia, the next step is some car travel to Macedonia and then onwards to Albania. Our last stop will be Tirana, in Albania.

 

The group would like to have some information sent to me to start this travel planning out:

 

A quick overview of each country’s political climate - I don’t want anyone getting into trouble and having this turn into some geopolitical affair! Is the country at war with a US ally? Is the country in political turmoil? Is there a US embassy? Is it safe to travel there now?

 

This will be a good start for the travel planning. Please research these items and send the information to me right away.

 

Kind regards,
